content.rendered:
When I was in school I had a strong wish to teach children. Every year on teacher’s day I used to play my role as my favorite teacher which gave me an overwhelming satisfaction and happiness. I didn’t know that life would give me an opportunity very soon.

Back therein Nadiad, before the pandemic I use to visit Bhumel village every Sunday. It was the most awaited day for me as the children there waited for us volunteers to play with them. Of course, teaching and learning is always the second priority for kids! Still, without any argument and reluctance, they use to obey us and study sincerely.

It all had started in an event. DDU connect had arranged an Open Mic event as we were freshers and didn’t know about any clubs in the college. At the end of the event, one of the seniors who worked in the connect team addressed Anurakti Foundation in one of his conversations. He told everyone that it is an NGO that teaches slum areas and unprivileged children. I couldn’t refrain myself from asking him to take me as a volunteer.

A stream of joy surged throughout my body as I thought that I will be able to fulfill my promise that was made to my middle school social studies teacher. She asked each one of us to take a pledge that we may teach at least one underprivileged child in our lifetime.It was a totally different experience for me as I had never taught anyone before. I never imagined everything would go so well on the very first day itself. The children connected with me as well as cooperated with me very well. As soon as we finished teaching, I played with them and enjoyed a lot. Those were the most mesmerizing experiences I ever had in my life. The strong connection I made with the children draws me towards them every Sunday.

Apart from learning how to teach, I met a bunch of extraordinary people who were not only excellent in teaching but also knew how to endure children with so ease. Looking into the lifestyle of the children I taught I came to know that I was very lucky to be born in a family who was capable of admitting me to a private school. We all really felt that we should help children in every way possible.

Gradually we volunteers decided to take some snacks for the kids. Every time we serve them they just start making wishes what they want to eat next time and that made me feel so happy about them. Every time we leave they use to ask us if we will be coming next Sunday or not. Currently, it has become so awful for me that I am not able to visit them regularly. Still, there is hope in my heart that I will be able to visit them very soon.

Gautam Gandhi

AUTHOR
IT 3rd Sem

Bhargav Bhatiya

DESIGNER
IT 3rd Sem

Every year on teacher’s day I used to play my role as my favorite teacher which gave me an overwhelming satisfaction and happiness. I didn’t know that life would give me an opportunity very soon. Back therein Nadiad, before the pandemic I […]

content.rendered:
Since the dawn of the kings, fortresses have been a major part in any kingdom’s defence. Loaded with cannons and powerful artillery these fortresses were the last line of defence for any kingdom. They represented the glory and strength of their ruler and the country. The history of mankind has witnessed many tall, powerful and unconquerable fortresses. But for a 10-year-old, who needed his mom’s permission to take a single step out of his house, the greatest and the most powerful line of defence was a fortress built from pillows and cloth.

Built by the finest engineer in the world, this fortress stood tall enough to protect me from any attack, at least for ten seconds. A huge accomplishment for a ten-year-old like me. The fortress was surrounded by canals made of soft quilts to ensure no one would dare cross the fortress. The walls of the fortress 2 feet tall made sure no one would ever dare ascend them. The walls made of the toughest pillows ensured that not even the strongest cannonballs would break through them. Inside the castle, the king’s strongest men were stationed, ferocious warriors whose names were known far and wide throughout the kingdom’s 10-metre territory. Just their names would make the enemies tremble in fear, gallants whose gallantries far exceeded their reputation. On the front gates stood the two 5 inch Gorilla-men whose punches would send the enemy forces flying out of the room. The artillery unit, led by Captain Giraffo would prevent any aerial attacks and destroy enemies at the farthest of distances. Inside the castle, General Leo led the leopard squad the strongest and the swiftest soldiers whose speeds depended on the ruler’s or rather my, mood. Mr. SpeedX the legendary biker and the kingdom’s swiftest fighter had a special inclined platform built for his special attack. When the special pillow platform would be raised by the ruler’s hands, Mr. SpeedX would rush into enemy lines and defeat his foes swiftly ensuring his king’s victory. But even if a foe is powerful enough to break through such an elite force, he would be forced to face the Archmage Athos, whose wand wielded the power to shake the heavens or rather the ceilings. The castle was destroyed count less times by parental attacks but was rebuilt by the resilience of its strong king.

Even now when I watch kids building sandcastles or home-made fortresses I fondly journey back to those old days and they teach me a lesson I could never forget. As a kid, when I built those fortresses I gave it my entire time and dedication even though I knew that it could be broken within a few minutes yet my dedication in building a new one was never faltered. But as we grow up we stop believing in our dreams at the slightest shadow of difficulty even though their life is much longer than these castles. The ability to never give up and rebuild ourselves is what we often lose as maturity enters our life. However, if we truly instil our childhood dedication into our dreams, maybe we can build them a lot stronger and make our dreams live a lot longer.

Mufaddal Suratwala

AUTHOR
IT 3rd Sem

Ammara Ahmed

DESIGNER
MBBS 2nd Sem

Loaded with cannons and powerful artillery these fortresses were the last line of defence for any kingdom. They represented the glory and strength of their ruler and the country. The history of mankind has witnessed many tall, powerful and […]

content.rendered:
The trouble being early is no-one there to appreciate it. Planning out about any task looks great on paper. Even though, I try to strive for something tremendous it happens to be accomplished by the end of the deadline. Even if I am given 4 months break to complete a task I would perch on the last day and would start my task. I could work very efficiently in the burden. my trait gave me contentment. I was never sure that by grabbing pride in such a vague habit, what I had been trying to demonstrate? Rather most importantly to whom. In this developing competitive world, this trait is referred to as a sense of irresponsibility.

The world of innovative ideas always opens up for me a few hours before my deadlines. No-one encouraged me and none could understand my perception, I was repeatedly told that the task is given never changes on the first day of submission as well as on the last day of submission. As time flew I was accustomed to all those cold scathing remarks. That consistently said you are brilliant enough and capable enough to finish off your work before time and set up as an example for others. But being sluggish ruins it all! There was a deep physiological fact related to it that is first you admire the person for who you are and then you say with some modification you would be at your best. The main question is why should I change? My mom and my school faculties had dealt with me the same way. You know when a mommy decides to accomplish a task no-one would think about messing up with her in her agendas.

My mom was way too clever wherever I use t o write my deadlines for the specific task she would erase it off and write a date 2-3 days ahead of the date provided. This strategy was a success until pre-school after that I avoided jotting down deadline. Still, all the wisdom of being “on-time” was bestowed upon me year after year. All the undertakings were futile. Several instants I have even felt that working on last-minute, no doubt gives rise to innovative opinions. Many times make me feel overwrought, and even during those last moments of my submission, I would ponder what I was doing, up all the time. And ended up criticizing my inner self that minding so much arrogance was not reasonable for me. Amidst all these “Postpone” is elation to my spirit. If things get postponed then my speed of work also gets halted. As it is said that a dupe always learns from his own experience and a rational man learns from others’ experiences. An extraordinary lesson was waiting for me.

I recollect one such instance where we were facing a power cut. I remember it so vividly that this date my mom makes fun of that. Actually, I had forgotten to pay the electricity bill in spite of given hundreds of reminders by my Mum, Dad, and Google Calendar. Regardless of my habit to put off things for the Last Date. It just slipped through my mind. The following day we were having a test at school and to this date, my mother has still kept my answer sheet. It appears to be a token where finally I comprehended that it was high time to get disconnected with the deadlines. Soon I began thinking that maybe it’s high time now and some serious modifications need to be uploaded on my Life Drive. Oops, I just forgot I have an assignment due tomorrow.

Muskan Vora

EC 3rd SEM

Even though, I try to strive for something tremendous it happens to be accomplished by the end of the deadline. Even if I am given 4 months break to complete a task I would perch on […]

content.rendered:
Vintage, cottagecore, dark academia, pastel. Wait, this isn’t another story about good old school times. These are just a few words that would be appropriate for my “aesthetic” or, for the layman, the way I integrate my visual preferences like color palettes, and themes in my everyday life. Let me clear this out as well, it isn’t just about the visual appeal, but aesthetics are in themselves a lifestyle. As cliché as it sounds, they let you shape your preferences and guide your decisions. For me, it is just a methodical approach to ground my hedonistic desires, and at the same time let me discover my individuality.

It is quite a privilege to be able to have multiple miscellaneous objects at your disposal, and to be able to choose from them, so why not make the most of what we have? Why not express our inner self ever so subtly yet so loudly with everyday commodities? My aesthetic revolves around that of my phone. Even though that one object, in particular, is capable of expressing a thousand things, I try to add a little more to every new addition to my collection.

For starters, my phone came in a glossy green finish. Too flashy for some people, but perfect for me. To be honest, I am more of a blue person, but this time green appealed to me more. After choosing it, I decided to dig up what green stands for. I started with our Tiranga and found that green stands for fertility and growth. That fit quite well, considering that I was getting through a new phase in my life altogether. I was growing up for real, so to say. Since I am a believer in the roots of Vedic literature, I found that it also stands for the heart chakra, Anahata. Again, this was relevant to considering that I was following my heart and stepping into the world of medicine.

However, this just wasn’t enough for me. I have always loved blue. When I was a child, one of the most common things grown – ups used to ask me was my favorite color, and why, and I always used to say sky blue, because the sky has no limits. They shrugged it off because it was a common reply, but little did they know how much it would go on to shape my personality. How I would hate being constrained and stopping because it had been “enough”. These are pretty aggressive and antisocial qualities to have, but when there’s kindness and passion and wisdom in this equation, it becomes a perfect recipe. And blue binds it all together, the vastness of the sky, the depth of seas, and quenching of thirst. It is my childhood, the essence around which “me” as a person has been wrapped around in layers by my experiences and time. Hence, it was an unavoidable addition in the form of a case. It is a liquid marble case with various shades of blue, further strengthening the need for fluidity and inclusivity. Since the lockdown gave too much free time, I spun up some old colors with glitter and painted my black watch to suit my phone; green with speckles of blue.

My aesthetics don’t end here, rather they’ve just begun. I added a sticker of an owl at the phone grip, for its symbolic value. An owl firstly has a vision in the night, and that is extremely necessary in this ruthless world. Foresight is not a gift, it’s a necessity. Secondly, in Hindu mythology, an owl is the vehicle of Goddess Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth, fortune, and success. My preference for this point wasn’t in hopes of supernaturally receiving wealth, but instead because of the stealth and dexterity, since Goddess Lakshmi is known to be very agile. Lastly, the owl is the symbol of Goddess Athena in Greek mythology, who is the goddess of wisdom and intellect. As an offering to these gods, I wanted something simple yet ancient, obvious but covered in layers, and there it was.

I could go on about my wool braided earphones and a simple silver earring, bu t that would be boring. The point of this article is to incite that spark in you that seeks to be seen while being hidden, in plain sight; the spark dripping with individuality that has been absorbed from various cultures, and to create an environment that fills you with joy, and satisfaction, to create your own aesthetic.

Dhruv Pathak

1st Year MBBS

These are just a few words that would be appropriate for my “aesthetic” or, for the layman, the way I integrate my visual preferences like color palettes, and themes in my everyday life. Let me clear this out as well, […]

content.rendered:
As I sit in my backyard, waiting for a perfect opening line to pop up in my mind, I realise how I’ve spent an hour behind it. The ferocious backspace of the keyboard and the self evaluating nature of mine jostle me back to the reality each time I dive deep into my thoughts. But why can’t I ink my thoughts on a simple piece of paper?

I remember how everything used to be just about reading or writing for me. I’d spend hours reading books, hunting down new words to brew my vocabulary and devoting myself to those new words by making them my fillip. I wasn’t even an avid writer then but it was something I was ardent about. While now as I sit trying to meet my deadlines, I am just “lost”. My pen feels a blurry and vague orbe around it, which screens it from all the beautiful and interesting things it could ink about.

Maybe I am partly responsible for the unjust to my pen. The days which were spent writing poems about mountains, oceans and clouds are spent on uploading stories of the same. The excitement of reading a new page everyday is replaced by the excitement of playing a new video game match every hour. The intrigue in creating new fictional characters and sculpting their lives is taken over by the intrigue of fictional movie characters. It wasn’t that long ago, but time felt different back then. Like there was more of it.

There’s a line from Flowers for Algernon which stuck with me big time, ” Would Charlie ever learn to read what was written in those balloons? If they gave him enough time -if they didn’t rush him or push him too fast -he would get it. But nobody has time” . It is funny as well as ironical that my “connection” to writing has apparently turned into a “dis-connection”. I have begun to struggle with all those “new” words I carry. Maybe if I give it a little time, I’d bring back the endemic traction. I’m sure this is something that every writer must’ve been through and I am no tenderfoot. I haven’t completely forgotten it, I believe I can still swirl my pen. And trust me, my pen misses it like the deserts miss rain. It is just trapped in a rut emaciated, but a little quencher is all it needs. I know it still dwells in the hinterland of my mind. Because if you take care of things, they last. If only everyone gave a little more time to their inner Charlies.

Priya Rathod

IT Batch 2018

The ferocious backspace of the keyboard and the self evaluating nature of mine jostle me back to the reality each time I dive deep into my thoughts. But […]

content.rendered:
What do we do first when we are born? We cry, right? But gradually crying turns into a medium of communication and later a way of expressing emotions. All animals can shed tears. Tear ducts are what separate the animal kingdom from others. Most beings use it to express pain and grief. Others use it as a mode of survival. But a question which I often ask myself is, do I need tears?

Sometimes I feel that I would be better off without tears. At many situations, they have been the cause of my embarrassment. Ruining my makeup and making me look like a racoon seems the part of its biological function. Not to forget that red eyes and nose and a puffy face isn’t presentable either. Such situations are very common with me. Like the time when I was supposed to collect my award and just cried out all my emotions. Or when I was in a play and was supposed to fake cry but ended up having real tears. And not to forget the movie night my friends had during which I ended up a bawling mess. Since then, I am the ‘cry baby’ of the group. Isn’t it awful for a person with her own voter id card?

But crying a lot has helped me in some ways. My eyes stay clear all the time and hence, fewer occurrences of eye infections. Lower stress levels and fewer headache s are some of the other health benefits. And it also has been a good way to win an argument. When I wanted to make a point more convincing, I simply cried once. It gained sympathy from almost everyone and eventually the competition. To escape a punishment, try bringing tears instead of stories. Even the lamest excuses could get you through, saying out of personal experience.

I have become more empathetic as a person. Over the years, I have learnt the signs that indicate a person is about to cry. An instinct has developed to comfort any and every crying person. So comforting others during their weak times is not an awkward situation for me; although sometimes I end up crying with them. But the satisfaction gained after helping is more than the embarrassment felt.

My tears are one of the loyal companions. They are there with me through all ups and downs. During lonely nights when I miss my dear ones. During my times of happiness. Or when going on gets tough. But after crying, I emerge stronger than before. And promise myself to not cry for the same reason again.

Sunayana Samavedam

EC 6th SEM

Tear ducts are what separate the animal kingdom from others. Most beings use it to express pain and grief. Others use it […]

content.rendered:
I was sitting on the last bench during my maths class when I scanned the entire room hoping to spot someone with the same confused face as myself. Not confused with the topic, confusion over the fact that there was something wrong with the fonts that sir was writing on the blackboard.

The digits were blurry, the formulas could not be made out and I could not be the only one too concerned about the impression I was going to make by telling sir about the problem. I struggled through the next hour, trying to improve my vision by squinting. That worked. But only for a few minutes before my eyes started to hurt and  I could squint no more. During this, the girl beside me noticed my actions and suggested me to have an eye exam as everything was alright with the teacher’s handwriting. Soon, I came out with the news that I didn’t have a clear vision after all. I was near-sighted. It was time to get brand new, wonderful glasses.

I got my first pair of glasses-frameless, pink coloured and metal-bodied. They had personality. I loved everything about them and was so excited to wear them. They gave me a sense of confidence that I’d never had before. There was an additional benefit of finally being able to see what was presented in front of me.  As much I loved them, however, after a year or so, I realized that glasses weren’t perfect. People gave me various names seeing them on my face. Every time the fear of losing them was there in my mind as it made me feel blind. I had to think twice before getting into a fight. They restricted me from doing many things from 3D movies to wearing branded goggles. There was a constant fear that I was going to hit in the face with a ball and end up breaking my glasses. So, I tried their substitutes but was brought back to them.

Over the years I’ve learned wearing glasses is nothing to be ashamed of, in fact, it’s pretty fantastic. They are amazing. I might never prefer anything in place of them. My morning starts with finding them here and there and at night I always forget to keep them aside. Now, I am accustomed to all the issues and have learnt to deal with them. Cleaning your glasses every five minutes isn’t worth it. So I am seeing the world through a layer of obviousness. Glasses have become a part of me. They show my serious side. But that hidden flash of blue shows my girly and fashionable side. They do not just allow me to see and go about daily life, but they are a part of my sense of personal style, and hence, personality as well.

Nidhi Shah

CE 6th SEM

Not confused with the topic, confusion over the fact that there was something wrong with the fonts that sir was writing on the blackboard. The digits were […]

content.rendered:
The entire day, while sitting in my bedroom, I was trying to concentrate on my work. But I was not able to do it. I couldn’t even feel hungry to eat my lunch. It was another stupid fight with my best friend. She is not just a friend but a family to me.

“I think I should apologise to her and initiate the conversation !” said my conscience for her .`

“Nah! Why should I? She never understands me. She needs to apologize first !” said my ego. And here is another victory for you. Congratulations!!! Ego.

 I started realising that these small fights are increasing day by day over small matters and sometimes without any reason. It was me who took the initiative and apologised to her keeping all our issues aside and finally after three days we had a friendly conversation.

Today, while sitting ideally near the window, enjoying the sunset and having spent another boring and unproductive quarantine day, I realised that Ego, you and I share an invisible yet an emotional bond. It was you who stopped me from crying when I hugged my brother for the last time when he was going away from me to a whole new country for further studies. It is you who stops me from messaging a friend first seeing him online. It is you who encouraged me to do photography even after reading the signboard, “PHOTOGRAPHY STRICTLY PROHIBITED”.  

And now thinking endlessly, I figured out that Ego, you always have an easy way out. You are always ready with a plan . You always compel me to pursue a wrong decision for all the wrong reasons you have. And not only that you also hide the working of real love from me by stimulating my senses and making me feel good about my every wrong deed.  I don’t know how but sometimes you make me more powerful. For a moment I feel that I have everything  But this feeling doesn’t last long as sooner or later I realise that I am wrong and was tricked by you to fall into a trap.

As the days pass by, the real me is getting replaced by an egoistic me. You have proven to be toxic for me, whose extreme dosage would have devastating consequences on me.

The more I try to stay away from our toxic relationship, more and more I get attracted towards you making our bond, even more, stronger than before.

# My ego writes the cheque that my body can’t cash.

Aastha Patel

CE 4th SEM

content.rendered:
It all started when my grandmother told me not to mess up my study table with watercolours. Hence, the closest thing similar to a table I could think of were stairs. I was eight and we led a simple life in a simple house near the busy market. We had these archaic wooden staircases, with seemingly high pitch line. So, I’d take my weapons, that is my paint brushes and scurry off to the chocolate brown cases. I’d place my stuff on one stair and sit on the next stair lower to it and I’d begin the sorcery. It’s funny how cold it felt beneath my skin, but still I found that tingly feel really amusing. The best part was having my lunch there because who wouldn’t like to eat with a TV on, promisingly at a level higher from the ground. The other place where I loved to run my chores was in the backyard. The stairs there were rubble blocks made of cement which lead to a store room and for the cherry on top, it had a cement handrail. So presently if you’re an adult but had never tried sliding down a handrail, then your childhood had been a sham. The best part of my childhood was there, near the dusty stairs with my cousins, building forts of mattresses and chairs and playing all day long till we looked like scarecrows and someone had to drag us out of there. We’d occasionally play the classic perpetual game of ‘how many staircases can you skip?’ and of course tripping over until one of us sprains a joint. Time passed and we decided to build ourselves a new home. I was mad as a hatter to know as to how the stairs will turn to look like. To be honest, I was more excited for the stairs than my own room. They looked like the ones you see or read about in the Greek or Roman mythology, except these were black marble instead of blinding white. Spiral staircases with two openings. I always felt it tough to decide as to which side to take to reach my room. Mother and I would decorate them with diyas during Diwali and they looked magnificent. I’d remove my glasses off and look at the beautiful bokeh it set in front of my eyes. After all these years, I’ve grown up and I live by myself in my hostel. Yet I still find myself sitting on the hostel stairs preparing for exams. My roommates would ask if I’m uncomfortable in studying around them but perhaps it is an old habit to find stairs for solace. As of now, while I’m writing this, I’m still seated on the grey blocks. I guess they really meant it when they said that beauty is in the eyes of beholder. From soup to nut, my childhood revolved around the ups and downs of stairs. And I still look forward on sitting on more staircases at more places, counting the number of stairs! And I’m pretty sure I’m clairvoyant about that!

Priya Rathod

IT, 4th Sem.

I was eight and we led a simple life in a simple house near the busy market. We had these archaic wooden staircases, with […]

content.rendered:
“Them that’s got shall have, Them that’s not shall lose 

So the Bible say, And it still is news 

Mama may have, Papa may have 

But God bless the child, That’s got his own 

Oh, the strong get more, While the weak ones fade 

Empty pockets don’t ever make the grade ….” 

This is all I remember. My mother used to sing me this lullaby which she says her mother used to sing it to her. It’s been 16 years since my mother died and this incomplete, half-remembered lullaby is the only memory I have of her. 

Today at work, the hours of my day went passing by without a whimper or a cry and wrapping up for the day while drifting in my thoughts, I reminiscence it- the lullaby. Maybe for an instance, the time had stopped, while I felt engulfed by my mother’s hug and scent and my mind drifted back to the time when she used to buy me cotton candies and then we spent the day aimlessly at the dock counting the ships and dreaming of chasing butterflies one day.

The sun was setting down today bright and shiny, yet subtle. It looked kind and at peace and made me feel at ease, the way my mother used to make me feel and again I memorized the lullaby because that’s the only string which keeps me connected to my mother. My skin felt the sun’s warmth and my heart smiled. The sun waved back at me as I waved it goodbye. 

As the sun set down, it brought darkness and fear with it. The moon was yet to rise and it was darkness all around. It made me freak out, panicked and I wanted to scream out loud but then I tried to remember the lullaby my mother used to sing to me when I was afraid. The words started flowing in my mind giving me strength and courage to stand against the dark. But this time it was different as I was all alone without my mother. But the lullaby kept on giving me strength and making me strong every moment so that I rise and become powerful enough to withstand the world all by myself.

This lullaby has not only taught me to be strong but, it has also inculcated some traditional values in me which I think makes my mother more than happy. At every step of my life whenever I needed my mother all I need to do was to memorize the lullaby in my mind and then at next moment I find my mother standing next to me holding my hands, supporting me. I don’t know but the lullaby was so hypnotic that it made me want to listen to it daily and maybe it was my mother’s voice which made it more musical.

Aastha Patel

CE, 4th Sem.

content.rendered:
Yes, I’m in love. In deep, untamed, uninhibited love that runs deep in my veins and stomach for that matter. I was at the doorstep, making my debut entrance at the La Pino’z. The irresistible smell, the aroma of flavours and the rich colours and everything else in the restaurant had me under control. I said to myself “Sruthi; this is gonna be the love of your life. Hold it tight and never let it go.” Well; for me the love of my life is not a human being rather is the different delicacies existing in the world. 

My passion for food is something that I cherish. Food is always benevolent. No matter what mood I am in, I can always count on food. It is always tempting, always! I consider that no time limit or place, or anything in the world can stand in the way of tasting and getting the fill of my favourite meal. 

I’m pretty sure that the thing which every host élite like me misses or craves for is Ghar ka khaana. Ghar ka Khaana is more like comfort food for me. It is something which makes me eager to wait for weekends so that I can get home as soon as possible. Even the khichdis and the dal chawal which I used to dislike, before coming to the hostel is overly loved by me now. Mealtimes are something which is not less than a celebration at my house. Waking up to the smell of ghee masala dosa and vada idli was usual for me. My Amma loves cooking and she is no less than a great chef when it comes to that. She doesn’t compromise with the taste. But after coming to the hostel, my taste buds have definitely started to compromise themselves to get used to the hostel food.

I like to call myself a foodie even after looking at the pretty numbers shown by my weighing machine. From sizzlers of Blueberrys to Dostana ki extra teekhi pani-puri, I have tried to cover everything in Nadiad. I’m highly grateful to the online food services in Nadiad. They have been a total saviour from the hostel food. Trust me; the discounts given by these apps can sometimes give you more goose-bumps than binge-watching an entire season in one night.

I know most people consider food as secondary to happiness but not me! I think being happy is getting your fill of favourite food in the company of your favourite people. Nothing can beat that, nothing! Let’s toast to that but before let me complete my slice of pizza.

Sruthi Cheruvullil

EC, 4th Sem.

The irresistible smell, the aroma of flavours and the rich colours and everything else in the restaurant had me under control. I […]

content.rendered:
Take a minute from whatever it is that you are doing and look up. Look up at that ethereal multitude of colours. Look up at the sun rays piercing through the ginormous clouds. Look up at that big, blue, infinite sky. Or if it’s dark, let the calling light of the moon fall onto your skin. Let the array of constellations show you the way to heaven. Close your eyes and feel every drop of the rain. In that moment, forget everything and everyone you know, because in some time it may not even matter. Feel the sky the way I feel it. Get lost in the infiniteness that will wrap around you even after you cease to exist.
We live busy lives. Or at least that is what we tell ourselves. Once upon a time, on one long day I took a moment to notice the sky. The bright blue was splotched by giant clouds. The sun shone on them in a way that made them look like angels watching over me. I was dumbstruck by its beauty. I felt tiny. For a long while, nothing seemed significant. I reflected upon my problems and wondered how many of them were even real. I felt something I never felt before. I stopped thinking of myself as a human, and thought of myself as a small part of the universe. In that moment, I devoted every fiber of my being to the sky.
“Once you have tasted the taste of sky, you will forever look up”
-Leonardo da Vinci
From that day on, I began observing all the tiny little things about God’s palette that made me love it even more. Forming dragons out of clouds, spotting constellations, waking up in the dead of the night to honor eclipses and meteor showers, and looking at hundreds of images of the northern lights because Norway is far away. There’s only joy in every part of this journey. Once when I am hypnotized by it, I can think of nothing else. But of course, I can’t stare at the sky all day. This little human has work to do. Yet, I can’t think of anything that I can achieve, that could even come close to being significant.
Often I feel that most of what I do, or what all of us do won’t even matter in the longer run. At times, I can’t help but feel that my existence is useless. But when nothing else seems permanent, I know for sure that the sky – the universe is. It has been there long before we came, and it’ll be there long after we are gone. For some reason, that gives me a sense of purpose.
The sky is the masterpiece of God. Yet, here we are lighting up fires and poking holes in its canvas. The sky is one of the few things that shows mercy on us. The sky is the only thing that shows mercy on this pale blue dot for a planet. It’s about time we start respecting that.

Khadija Sidhpuri

CE, 3rd Sem.

Look up at that big, blue, infinite sky. Or if it’s dark, let the calling light of the moon fall onto your […]

content.rendered:
“Mexican!” “Mexican!” “Mexican!” the only word I used to preach to my grandma as a kid whenever I wanted to eat Mexican, so much so that I came to be called as the ‘bhukkad’ of the house. ‘Enchiladas’ was the emotion behind the word ‘Mexican’, but my younger self didn’t know what it was called at the time. Having little or no idea about what Mexican was or what I was screaming about, she always nodded and smiled, and without a word, she went into the kitchen and made me her world-famous chole that everyone was a die-hard fan of. Only with a twist, the name ‘Mexican’ and lots of love was added with the chole; and so it was called ’The Mexican Chole’. I wish I could rebel the fact that it was not what I had asked for. But the glare in my mother’s eyes, which only said that it would be disrespectful of me to reject what I had been given, accompanied by the fresh, tantalizing aroma emerging out of it, always prevailed over its physical appearance and held me under shackles so tight that I could not revolt but eat. I remember I always fell in love with it.

Be it a festival, a weekend, a frantic day at sports class or a day when my exam results came out, all days had the same feeling- Mexican. I yearned for enchiladas and my grandma made me the Mexican Chole instead. The kid in me easily got flattered and I almost completely forgot that I had been so badly craving for enchiladas until this time, and got lost in the enchantment of the explosion of numerous flavors cast upon my taste buds. It was a dish filled with sentiments; emotions of love, affection, tranquillity, hope, enthusiasm and amusement. Hope, as she probably wished that I would like it and that she never gets tired of impressing me. Amusement, because I had to pretend that it was what I had asked for.

Years passed by. My cravings for enchiladas grew strong, but for the Mexican chole- stronger. I grew old and granny- older. I realised how troublesome I had been to her until this time, wanting her to fulfill my inexplicable demands. I noticed why she gave in to my wishes. It was never because she was old, but because she did everything for me out of love. How much she loved making people happy and how content she felt watching those happy faces while they ate her straight-out-of-heart chole and me, her Mexican chole.

Now that she is no more, I have never asked for the Mexican chole. I couldn’t accept the signature dish of my grandma being made by anybody else. If there’s one thing that has kept the bond between my grandma and me still alive in my heart, it is the Mexican Chole. The feeling still majestic, the taste still refined, the aroma still airy.

Snigdha Lokre

EC, 3rd Sem.

content.rendered:
“Come on Aastha, buckle up, stop staring at the sky. We are getting late for our lectures.” Somehow my friends and I managed to reach the class on time, but I couldn’t keep my eyes away from the window, watching the tiny drops, dancing their way down. Locked in a trance, I wondered how much importance a drop of water holds in my life.

Glancing at the rain outside the window, I remembered the mesmerizing feeling of raindrops falling on my face and breathing the earthy mist. For me, these raindrops are full of life and they shower love on everyone, though many can’t feel it. Today when these tiny droplets of rain came in contact with my skin, it felt like they were talking to me, narrating me the journey of their formation. They washed all my pain and left behind a trail of good memories which, unlike them, can never be wiped off.

After the rain stopped, seeing the water droplets falling off the leaves reminded me of dew. Waking up early in the morning and watching the crystal clear dew drops soothes my mind and makes me believe that there can be absolute clarity if you refine your vision. Whenever I see these dewdrops dancing at edges and sliding with great ease, they inspire me that they are not afraid of falling from that great height and yet keep on smiling. These wonderful particles of droplets are gems of the morning and without seeing them my morning is incomplete. I feel that dew like human tears are the tears of the leaves which are shed at night and wiped off early in the morning.

Speaking of tears, when my heart is heavy with emotions, they come out of my eyes bursting out like rain. Tears are always there for me but come into action when my heart wants to speak and my lips no longer describe my feelings. Sometimes, they just roll down my cheeks in the form of unspoken happiness. Many a time, they start pouring even when I don’t feel like crying but they convey what is hidden in my heart. My tears are more special to me than my smiles as they are reserved for only those whom I really love. It is rightly said that a drop of rain can melt a heart but a drop of tear can melt the toughest soul.

Regardless of it being in the form of rain or dewdrops, every time a drop appears in my presence, it ensures that I am happy. This is true even when the drop is in the form of a tear running down my cheek. Individually (as in dewdrop) or together (as in rain or tears) they are unbreakable and share a very strong bond and an essence worth remembering. They are just an inevitable part of my life. Sometimes, I wonder is it the drop that inspires me or the happiness that it carries with it?

Aastha Patel

CE, 3rd Sem.

Locked in a trance, I wondered how much […]

content.rendered:
My ears have been left sore after using them for hours at stretch. My earphones have never failed to hurt me after a Friends season ends. But to get the pleasure of being left alone, one has to pay the price. I pay this price every time I feel like leaving this world behind by using my earphones as a means to travel to another dimension. It transforms into a portkey when I listen to a Harry Potter audio book or into a Golden Chariot during storms when Hanuman Chalisaa plays in the background. Earlier it used to be an escape but now, it has become an integral part of my life.

I had first found them in my mother’s drawer just a few days before my college started. They were nothing more than a stubborn pair of tangled wires back then. It wasn’t until my bus rides to home increased that I started using them as a way to escape strangers’ silent stares. With soft music playing in my ears and the beautiful scenery passing by, my life seemed nothing short of a Zoya Akhtar movie. Slowly, they entered into my night routine. With the ever-increasing journal submissions and proportionally decreasing motivational level, I needed something to keep me on track. In came the ’90s and ’70s romantic playlist which made my insomniac nights easier and soon those white earphones became a part of me.

It wasn’t long before I realised how mysterious they really were. They had ways to transform a sad, post break up mood into a more socially accepted stoic one. They made me slide in my parent’s bed at night after it elevated the effects of a horror movie. They evoke a foreign emotion when I noticed my roommate looking longingly at me and my laptop as I watched Netflix a day before her sessionals. Google titles this feeling as being sadistic. I felt my mother’s presence miles away from home with our innumerable video calls. After a long day at college I unwind myself  lounging in bed with my earphones in and a stand-up comedy playing on my mobile.

But it wasn’t always like this. There was a time when I used to be intimidated by people walking down the pathway with wires dangling down their ears. Now I am on the other side of the road. I still have to find out if this much craving for a thing will actually be beneficial for me. But right now, I am a bit busy with tasks which require my white wires within an arms distance.

Divyashree Iyer

IT, 3rd Sem.

But to get the pleasure of being left alone, one has to pay the price. I pay this price every time I feel like leaving this world behind by […]

content.rendered:
“So where are we going to live now?”
“Saudi Arabia.”
When I was expecting mom to say USA or something, she said a name I’d never heard of. I was seven years old when my dad landed a job in Yanbu, KSA. Of course, being in a plane, getting to live abroad excited me beyond limits. But it was only after we moved there, that I realized that I would never be able to see my old friends or even go back to my old home again.
Moving to Saudi felt like moving to a different planet. From the language to the inverted traffic lights, everything was new. Saturday became the first day of school instead of the last. The cartoons I loved started talking English instead of Hindi. “Maafi Arabic,” – was the only Arabic sentence I knew and spoke, which means “I can’t speak Arabic.” The part I hated was that there were zero theatres in the country. More than anything else, I wanted to go back to my old home.
Yet, my surroundings found an easy way to distract me from my hatred. Each detail of this new planet was fascinating and overwhelming. I began to see beauty in things I despised. The evergreen trees and grassy hills were replaced by sand dunes and rocky mountains. Getting lost while exploring the enormous shopping malls was nothing less than a treasure quest. The gigantic Arabian horses never ceased to amuse me. The beaches were the best of all!
Coming from a land that is known for its rivers, I found most odd that Saudi had zero rivers or freshwater lakes. We were lucky to be living in a coastal city. When I first went to the beach, it was love at first sight. Splashing around the infinite shoreline and collecting seashells became a weekend thing. I still have daydreams about sitting on the wet sand, gazing at the sunset, with a shawarma in one hand and a can of ‘bebsi’ in another. The breathtaking motorboat and buggy rides were the cherry on top. Walking over sand dunes and having your feet engulfed in the fine sand was scary and ticklish at the same time. I was fascinated by this new costume called burqa, but sadly I was too young to get one myself.
After having lived in KSA for four years, it was time to move back to homeland India. This meant, losing all my friends again and starting over. I hated that part of the process. I felt sorry for many of my new classmates who asked me how I could survive in Saudi for that long, who thought of it as a place where all fun goes to die. They had only seen the black part of the picture. Sure, the country had its flaws, but who doesn’t? For as long as we lived there, I had only known happiness, respect, security and above all unrivaled experiences. Four years may not be long enough to call it home, but I spent a lifetime over there.

Khadija Sidhpuri

CE, 3rd Sem.

content.rendered:
“Hey Alexa, play songs from my music library”- these were the first words, I heard when I entered my home from my mundane Hostel for Diwali vacation. Amazon echo or “Hamari pyaari Alexa” came to my house this July. My brother received it as a gift from his industry, and he re-gifted it to my parents. In the beginning, my parents found it difficult to talk to her and I thought the next time I come home, I’ll find her in dust in one of the corners in my small house. Well, I was totally mistaken. When I came back home, I realized that they were completely obsessed with her. Their day started with her and ended with her.

Despite these facts, Alexa didn’t raise my interest in it. In my mind it was just a conversational bot and how exciting could that be? I already know that I could ask Alexa things, something I should get used to. But I’m not much of a talker when it comes to speaking to inanimate objects. On the last day of my Diwali vacation, I heard my mom asking her, “Alexa, honey could you please stop the music”. A sudden rush of thought came to my mind that Alexa gets spoken to better than me, and she was not even real. I went straight to her and said loudly, “Hey Alexa, I don’t like you”. Prompt came the response “I am really sorry to hear that. You can always send feedback through the help and feedback section through the Alexa app.” Well; at least everyone in the house had a hearty laugh.

It’s not that I hate Alexa, but the factuality that how artificial intelligence has taken over our lives makes me bothersome. I know artificial intelligence is the future waiting for us and of course, it is beneficial. But somewhere deep I think it will shatter the thin line between reality and fantasy. Many people, including the late physicist Stephen Hawking, have raised concerns that the rise of powerful AI systems could spell the end for humanity. The fact that AI is dubbed “intelligent” is ultimately down to the fact that it can learn. But even when it comes to learning, it is no match for humans. In fact, toddlers can learn by just watching somebody solving a problem once. An AI, on the other hand, needs tonnes of data and loads of tries to succeed on very specific problems.

Machine learning and artificial intelligence are tools. They can be used in a right or a wrong way, like everything else. It is the way that they are used that should concern us, not the methods themselves. Human greed and human ignorance scare me far more than artificial intelligence does.

Sruthi Cheruvullil

EC, 2nd Sem.
